Akatsuki no Yona is very on & off (GOOD AT SOME PARTS, VERY BAD ON OTHER PARTS) with A LOT of things but if you piece it in your mind then you'll be fine.

It has a plot that'll keep you watching but I personally don't think it would be in your Top 30 if you had to make a "Best Anime" list for every Anime you'd ever watched.

Yona of the Dawn is an amazing anime with very few flaws. Its creative story line is a nice break from the traditional action/romance anime themes that are most common in the Japanese animation industry. With interesting characters, great voices, and a suspense at the end of each episode that keeps the audience hungry for more, this anime is a must see for any anime enthusiast. That said, the anime did contain some lack of character development, and while the sound track for the first half of the season was magnificent, the fitting instrumental music was soon replaced with vocals that didn't quite embody thestory or main character. In addition, the show did maintain its smooth and entertaining plot development very consistently until the very last episode, which was a great disappointment as it both rushed to finish the initial story line and left so many questions unanswered. All in all, Yona of the Dawn was riveting and entertaining, and had it not scrambled to conclude its story in the briefest way possible, this anime just might have earned a perfect score.

Shoujo fans, rejoice. Here comes an anime that will most definitely salvage the genre among the cliché fest that seems to reign it these days. 
Anime in general seems to be suffering a lot  about being fairly generic these days. All shounen comedy seems to be an ecchi harem, just like its action counterpart ahs the hot-blooded, determinator archetype as a main character. Shoujo has been infested with a horde of main female leads shallow enough for the viewer to easily self-insert without feeling remorse, which are usually friendless and pretty without realizing they're pretty. Which, by the way, falls in love with theequally shallow guy, which is more often than not a complete jerkass who very unrealistically 'changes' for the aforementioned Bella S-- *cough* female lead.


This, I'll emphasize, is the norm, not the rule. There are plenty of shoujo that soar over the sea of mediocrity and even  several of them who decompose the previously mentioned overused plots. Kudos to them, for being standouts on their own right.


And kudos to Akatsuki no Yona, which didn't fall behind.


The story, I'll admit, is not entirely original, thus I had to give it a seven even though I certainly didn't want to). A girl goes on a journey to look for certain items that will help her achieve her goal, basically. However, I have to give my praise to the background. It's set in a fictional Korean-like kingdom called Kouka, whose problems are apparently scarce. The female lead, a princess, has lived indifferent and ignorant about all that lies outside. Then a certain major event forces her out and in look for the four dragons, legendary creatures who will her help retake the castle and overthrow a traitor who stripped her from all she knew.


Even though the pace is slow, I honestly never felt the episodes pass, and more often than not I couldn't believe that was all. Each character has an arc, which is never a bad idea of well-executed. And this being the gem it is pulled it off effortlessly.


Certainly a standout among the winter 2014 anime, Akatsuki no Yona offers a pleasure to the eyes with beautiful character designs, elaborated backgrounds and very solid animation. Very few frames seemed out of place and characters were seldom drawn out of proportion. 

Same goes to the soundtrack, which greatly complimented the overall feel of the anime and in my opinion was only overshadowed by Tokyo Ghoul's (overhyped as hell, but great OSTs) and a couple others. Bonus points for the opening being instrumental as well.


The characters were a pleasure. An actually likeable female lead!? I had to be dreaming, except I wasn't. Yona manages to be spoiled, selfish and inmature the first episodes and still be endearing from the start. We see her grow and accept her hardships the way very few other leads could manage to do. She cries and whines, sure, but who can blame her? And she actually makes an effort to improve as an individual. Perhaps my favorite female character of the season.

Side characters weren't left behind, which was great. Hak was one hell of an eye candy with a personality to match, acting as the 'normal' one until the appearance of another character at the later half, and even then he was farily weird.


A moment of silence for him being friendzoned in absolutely epic proportions as well. I swear I had never cringed as much as I did with this poor guy. 


Every character was fairly developed and had a farily unique personality. The team waifu, a smallish boy called Yoon, gets a special mention because of the huge housewife potential he has. I swear no person would live unhappy with a guy like that.

There's Jae-Ha, one of the dragons that despite his relatively little screentime quickly became the most interesting personality-wise, and Kija, a rather childish guy who can even pull of being annoying and endearing at the same time. And a character that appears exclusively at the last chapter, Zeno, a keet and a shota (what's not to love?) who acts silly but is obviously far more intuitive than his demeanor shows.

Hell, even the antagonist is well-made to the point I find it hard to hate him. Scratch that, I still want his head to roll, but I do get his intentions, if you get me. And a good villain is a huge, huge plus to me. Possibly my favorite cast in the season as well.


I have but one complaint, and that is Shina. I had such high hopes for him the moment he was introduced and even after the joined the group. Problem is, he was put far behind on the sidelines to the point he had one, two lines of dialogue at most in the latter episode. They could've at least tried making him relevant the way they did with Kija even if his arc had long passed.


Needless to say, this whole show was a delight to watch. Great characters, animation, a well-executed plot and an OST to match? I can't go as far as to call this a masterpiece... yet. It sure as hell has the potential. A gem among anime, and a definite must-watch among fans of shoujo.

Did i give it my all before i last gave up on doing something? Were my thoughts of giving up being okay because i gave my best only to console myself? Such were the thoughts running through my head as i was watching this gem of the season, reflecting upon the times where i gave myself empty consolations on how it was okay to give up because I gave my all when thinking back i never actually did try my hardest. This anime struck a chord within me and possibly many of the other viewers, and if you havent watched it yet,for any who like watching the growth and developments of characters as they progress, or those who simply want to enjoy a nice adventure from the back of your seats, this anime is for you as you will be in for a thrilling rigde with moments that bring you joy and laughter, moments with thrill and excitement, moment filled with inspiriation and moments which would tug your heartstrings as you enjoy this wonderfully animated series of Akayona. 


   The story kicks off with our red haired princess, yona, losing her father, her sole parental figure who accompanied through her growing years to her childhood friend whom she always played with adored. Betrayed by her love and losing her father, yona's beliefs were shattered as the world around her, the days where she could spend in peace and tranquility crumbled. Just as she was staring deep into the abyss of despair and almost silenced, she was saved in the nick of time by her bodyguard and childhood friend.  


   Henceforth begins the journey of the sheltered princess Yona as she transverses the continent, learing about the harsh realities surrounding the world while slowly progressing to be a figure worthy to lead, one who inspires people to follow her as her caliber as a person is tested multiple times throughout her journey.


  This series is wonderfully animated starting from the crimson red hair of yona and the well represented characters to the various castles, buildings and landscape with colours and brightness which fits very well with the story and mood settings of the anime. What I feel was done particularly well was yona's fury mode with regards to the art as it fully depicted her fury while bringing along a sense of anticipation to the following actions she would take to resolve her fury.


  The op and ed tracks were also well made to suit the mood of the story with appropriate insert songs at moment where there was a major event happening, particularly the tune in episode 22 which really fit the mood of the snipe.


 There was also great character development throughout the series with clear and steady plot progression, and was well-paced throughout the series after the first 3 episodes which might come off as a slightly slower start to some. 


   All in all, akayona was an interesting and enjoyable watch, packed with loads of action and development with ample laugh and a pinch of romance to complete the package but still the anime left much of the plot hanging and many praying after finishing the anime, praying towards the hopes of a season 2.... 


To anyone reading this who hasnt watch it yet why not give it a try? I may not have much knowledge about your tastes in anime but I can assure that this is a great watch, a gem awaiting discovery.

This is my very first review

I was honestly blown away.
I gave this anime a 10 because everything about it is amazing. 
The storyline, the artwork, the characters were all phenomenal!
Let's start from the beginning: Yona is a frail princess, living with her father, King IL.  Yona starts as a dislikable character, her weakness, and brattiness showing making her annoying at first. When the man she loved -- Soo-Won-- killed her father right in front of her eyes, traumatizing her. But, after her father's death she is motivated to become stronger, and not let anyone die. She wants to fulfill the prophecy of the four dragons that came from theheavens to once fight beside King Hiryuu who founded the country, and fought against the humans, who wanted to kill him.\n\n
Yona is supposedly King Hiryuu's descendant, and she was told to find the four dragons, and get together, and fight along side each other like they did many centuries ago. (*COUGH, COUGH* REVERSE HAREM *COUGH*). \n\n
I definitely recommend this to ANYONE. They also mix so many genres into the series, (romance, adventure, combat, etc). It's adorable, and will definitely make your heart melt. I'm hoping there will be a second season very soon! It has also turned into my new favorite anime EVER. I don't think anything could possibly beat it.

This anime had an interesting world to explore, a strong start, good characters, and a story that really made me want to go along for the ride. The problem is it never really goes anywhere. Sure they have to round up some allies before they storm the castle but it just doesn't feel like anything gets done because they never explain how rounding up the allies will help them accomplish any of their goals. Yes they are legendary warriors but if a regular human is better than them what makes them so necessary?
The story is basically just: "We need to do the thing." And thenit never explains why they need to do the thing. Same thing with the Antagonist. Spoilers for episode one to follow: He betrays his childhood friend and the girl that loves him by killing the king but it never explains what any of his goals are or what led him to believe the king deserves to die. Sure it explains that someone told him something that made him want to kill the king, but why would he believe that information and act on it and where does he plan to go from there?


If you are telling a story by the time you are 24 episodes in you better give your audience a clear grasp of what the hell is going on and what your character's goals are. I want to like this story, I really do. It has cool characters and the way they build up their bonds is really nice and everything that happens in the show is done well, it is an enjoyable show. It just doesn't feel like it has any direction because one is never provided. In episode 24 both the protagonist and the antagonist are asked what their plans are and one says "idk lol" and the other says "lol watch"... for the love of god tell us what is going on! They don't even explain what the "true powers" of her allies are or why the thing that is supposed to happen when they all assemble didn't happen.


Also it feels kinda like they ran out of time so for recruiting the fourth dragon (spoilers) he just shows up and joins them and doesn't appear to have any powers.


Other than not defining where the journey of the antagonist and protagonist were going and (I believe) running out of time and rushing the last episode or two the only things the show did that actually annoyed me were 3 traits of the princess:

1) Relationship obliviousness - typical main character bs. Your bodyguard wants to impregnate you, she really should have realized this numerous times.

2) She has red hair - everyone is looking for a "red haired princess"... dye your hair! You're on the run and have a single identifying trait! Do something about that!

3) Death stares are not real - just because you look at someone with a determined look in your eye and are a beautiful princess does not mean they are going to give a crap, especially when they clearly have the upper hand in the situation. Please stop doing this every time something bad happens to magically intimidate your way out of trouble.


Honestly though those are minor gripes and the vast majority of the show is good. My main problem with it is that it could easily be great but just doesn't seem able to pass that barrier because it is afraid to break away from tropes. 7/10 show overall. Think of it as a not as good version of Arslan Senki.

While it starts off a little slowly, this anime (along with it's manga) has easily made it's way up into my top 5. It's an anime which I honestly did not expect to get so attached to in the beginning, but something about it is so endearing that even in the beginning during the slow-paced introduction there is always something that grabs your attention and makes you want to know more about the world and it's characters. The only thing I wish they would have changed, or should do in the future, is add a few episodes or make a season two as it ended at a relatively odd spot in the story.

!! POSSIBLE SPOILER WARNING !!
Alright. Here we go. Let’s talk about this train wreck. Thank you Perriot for terribly adapting a rather well written manga that one can enjoy thoroughly.
Story: 3
Holy crap. What was this? This was pointless. If there were two seasons, the ending might pass but what is this? Pierrot clearly ruined a story that would have been an enticing adventure. There isn’t even a real reason for Yona to be gathering all the dragons. We are never told an actual reason. I suppose it is to take back the kingdom from Su-won, but what the hell? What is she going to doif she ever fights him? Kill him? Now what? Is Yona going to rule now? Her whole journey seems pointless. The story isn’t even consistent all the way through. Plus, the whole unfolding of events is stupid and we can especially see this when Pierrot rushes the meeting of Zeno (the yellow dragon) because they ran out of episodes. There is clearly meant to be a season 2. We can easily tell this because of the cliffhangers and such that we are left on. We can see that Zeno has more to him than he is letting on. There is so much that was introduced that would have been pointless without a season 2. Way to go Pierrot. You guys really did a great job ruining this adaptation.


Sound: 7

Eh. Sound isn’t terrible and they have a rather all-star voice actor lineup for the sub, in my opinion. I personally really liked the dub in general. But that can probably be acquitted to the fact that it is in my native language. But besides that, to me, the sub voice actors are really good and I personally like subbed Yona more than the dubbed one. Yona’s dubbed VA annoyed the HELL out of me. The OP’s and ED’s are pretty good. I personally like them more than quite a bit of other shows. But, sometimes the insert songs seemed out of place. Other times they were done well and really added to scenes but sometimes I also felt myself distracted by the OST. I think that good insert songs shouldn’t interrupt you watching a show but just add to the scene without you realizing it much.


Art: 8

The art in this was pretty good. I really liked the characters for the most part and the way they looked. The character designs were great. Each characters attire drew me in and suited them. They did a good job here. They didn’t have a ton of detail like a Kyoani, but it wasn’t terrible. The OP and ED’s looked good too, as they should. They were all done well and made me enjoy watching them to an extent.


Characters: 2

Well. It really sucks to give this a 2. I really don’t know if I can give it anything above this. The character development is a joke. No one has any real story. Shin-ha, Hak, Yun, and Su-won, are the only 4 characters that ever get any development. Yona and Jae-ha go under a bit of development but not enough. Most characters turn out exactly how we suspected when introduced to them, and no one really goes anywhere. They all are the same way mostly when we are introduced to them as they are at the end of the show. Most of them suck too. Hak is the only character worth watching in this show. His self-sacrifice makes him admirable and Yona, even after brought up by Yun, never thanks him for all he does. Maybe she does thank him once or twice and I am just forgetting about it, but I guarantee she never does it more than that. She doesn’t change besides the fact that she gets angry when other people get hurt. She is the stereotypical, “I care about everyone but can’t do anything about it,” MC. Hak and Shin-ha are the only two characters I ever gave a flying frick about. Everyone else pretty much sucks.


Enjoyment: 3

Well, I did enjoy it for a time but the more I watched it, the less I enjoyed it. I really feel like giving it a 3 in the enjoyment category is even a stretch.


Overall: 4.6

Well, this is it. It wasn’t great overall and the art and sound are the only things that I don’t hate, besides Hak and Shin-ha. I'm going to go ahead and round this down to a 4 because of the atrocity it is. Forget this show and Pierrot. I can’t believe people gave this show above a 6.

Yona is the story of a fallen Princess. She was living the life man! Good food, clothes, jewels. Sixteen and on easy street. Of course that had to change. Out of the castle she now wanders the land with her boy toy Hak. He's certainly able to take care of himself. However, they both discover that they need help if they want to survive.
This leads us to the brunt of the story as Yona is given a message by a priest, "Seek out the four dragon warriors." These four are the reincarnations of the dragons that served the king from a thousand years ago.Waiting for the return of their king.


Taste: The show was delicious. I really liked our heroine Yona. She grows as a person throughout the show, and you can see her turning from the helpless girl in distress to a strong leader that inspires her companions to follow her. And that's what this show is about in the end. The growth of Yona. As she travels her nation she sees how the people have suffered under her Father's rule, and her desire to help them, along with the guilt she feels about having been so out of the loop.


We can also see how they do a good job of developing each of the other characters, why the dragons are how they are, and what drives them. There is a bit of the reverse harem action going as you can tell each character is really falling for Yona. She of course is totally oblivious.


On the negative, I think the show drags out a bit. And there's a lack of intensity to me. They might also be missing a true big bad, or it could just be a scene that really makes you feel as though there's a chance it can slide away from the beaten path. I'll give taste a 7.5 out of 10


Presentation: This show had some good art, nothing that made me really go wow, but nothing that made me feel like they were low on budget or just lazy. When they did go into using more chibi art, it always seemed like it fit the situation. The music is kinda in that same area. I didn't have anything really stand out, but there wasn't anything that made me want to mute the show. Plus the voice work (Subs) was really well done. I'm going to give this a 3.5 out of 5 as well


Originality: When you get down to it, this is a pretty simple story, nothing to really say a curve ball has been thrown anywhere. Of course, I'll always say that it's not always a bad thing. Sometimes a story going how it should is well, how it should go. It just means you need to have solid characters and good story telling, which this show does. I'll give originality a 2.5 out of 5


In conclusion, I liked the show. I marathoned it pretty hard! And then I hunted down the manga. So I'll be reading that. Looks like it's a 13.5 out of 20 I strongly suggest watching this show!

I've always loved movies, shows and anime where strong and independent women kick the buts of some men. Akatsuki no Yona or Yona of the Dawn is one of that kind. Seriously, I love this anime and 24 episodes...Worth it! The fact that there is no release date of season 2 really makes me wanna cry.
Plot and Storyline
The pretty, little story begins when pretty, little Princess Yona witnesses the murder on her father King II of Kouka. The killer is on one else but her great love Soo-Won (From the moment I saw him I knew that he was devil him-self). Yona couldn't of cursestay in the palace so she runs away with her best friend and bodyguard Hak. After meeting the oracle Ik-su they decide to find some "Special Allies" (They are really special, I just don't want to spoil the story) and fulfill Yona's destiny as the Princess of Kouka, take back and save the Kingdom. \n
It's a for now unfinished story of a girl turning into a woman. Love, sadness and determination are mixed up with a great and interesting storyline along with some background stories about the main characters.\n
Characters    \n
The characters are typical like in every other anime story. We have the good guy, the bad villain and the pretty girl. But when we talk about each character in Akatsuki no Yona I have to admit that they are unique, specific and that they have that tiny spark inside that determines who they really are. \n
Yona: Oh Yona, Yona... In the beggining she really is a naive and little princess but also determine. Exactly that determination helped her to overcome all her obstacles and persuade on her way to strength. And her aura, you just have to love her like everybody else in the show does. \n
Son-Hak: I love this guy! He was always a down-to-Earth guy despite his talent, strength and fame as the "Thunder Beast". Although he was also Yona's friend since childhood, he had to live in the shade of Yona's love towards Soo-Won. A great warrior and an interesting character. Son-Hak! \n
Soo-Won: What to tell about Soo-Won? Well first thing's first, he was a great actor and lair. "Round of applause"! He really didn't show any weakness in killing Yona's Father. Revenge really is something (Interested now?).\n
King II: He reminds me of the cute, kind, little grandpa living next door. He hated weapons and war, and beacause of his all-the-time optimism his Kingdom soon started to lose strength. That's at least how we get to know him, but I am sure that he had a big secret under his tiny mustache. We'll hopefully find out in Season 2.\n
Animation\n
Maho Yoshikama (Character design) and Michie Watanbe (Art lead) really did a great job. Ten out of Ten. The only thing I don't get is the fact that they praise Yona all the time for her beautiful Red hair although I think it's actually Redish-Violet. I don't know. And if I would be asked to give the award for "Best Opening" I would definitely give it to Akatsuki no Yona-Opening 2. Here is a link for the YouTube video if you'd like to see it: Akatsuki no Yona (Opening2)\n
Conclusion\n
Akatsuki no Yona is an anime for evry...Girl, I think. I am not sure if boys would like it that much. It is not girly at all, it's just that boys might find the whole love story annoying. But hey, long live the feminism. Still, if I were a boy I would definitely give it a try.  \n
A great motivator and a love story to come. I hope the makers don't mess up the second season. \n\n
 Fingers crossed\n
Your AnimeGirl

This is one of those which I gave an 8/10 after a long time and also the only one which I stopped halfway because I was too greedy to finish it. 
Story: I was looking forward on seeing a story like this since ages! This anime has a totally captivating story and a plot that would keep you wanting more. It has all those powerful emotional elements that would definitely make you rate this one higher. From the start to the finish, Akatsuki No Yona delivers a powerful story of betrayal, love, loyalty and legend. To be honest, I even forgot that this was areverse harem because it was very serious and plot twisting at first. 


Art: The characters were drawn so beautifully that you can't take off your eyes from them. The scenic shots were done really well. Special mention for attractively characterizing "Shin-Ah" and making him a candidate for the best iconic male for year 2015. This is an anime which involves dragons, and dragons are very hard to draw.The clothing and accessories of the characters were done really well. The opening, however, is designed in a spoiler way which you will understand when you watch it. But that itself makes the audience know what would happen and yet you want to watch it because of the curiosity. 


Sound: I think one of the most powerful things in this anime was the music which was done by Ryo Kunihiko. First time ever you get to see an instrumental becoming an opening, who said you need words to decorate an anime opening? Akatsuki No Yona clearly proved that there's no need. The other endings and openings were really pleasant as well- you can listen to them without disappointment. The voice dubbing was really good, I think some unrecognized seiyus had the opportunity to make a breakthrough here.  


Character: I love the fact that the main group in this story had many characters of every variety. There was the positive one, the pervert, the mother, the loner, the loyal and the strongest "even though he wasn't a monster" one too. It's actually a small family to me and it's a great idea to make a reverse harem with. Each character has a unique background story which is equally interesting as the main plot. Also, the characters were introduced in a way that it would cause conflicts between them, which makes the audience more curious about it. Since this one is targeted for females, they've taken the trouble of adding a cute little squirrel which makes your heart warm and a huge urge to snuggle it. 


Enjoyment: I never wanted to finish this anime, because I already loved everything about it. Yona - From an ignorant princess slowly developing into one of the most badass female Anime characters... Well, she's still getting there though. This anime is really good.
Akatsuki no Yona is about a girl named Yona. She was a carefree Princess in her Kingdom, Kouka. One day, someone kills her father, who was the king, and the one who killed her father was her beloved. With the help of Hak, he grants revenge on the "killer" (You will see it Su-won enough). However, she doesn't have enough power even though Hak is on her side. By that, a priest tells her to gather all the4 dragons.


In my opinion, this season is just a build up. Yes, until the 24th episode, it's just a build up. You will not see Princess Yona granting revenge on the Kingdom by the end of the season. This season mainly focuses on how she develops from being an ignorant princess. This season also focuses on the 4 dragons and how they differ from each other. Honestly, it's bittersweet. Bitter because of the ending and sweet because on how I enjoyed this anime a lot. That's the reason why I gave the story a 7/10 because the anime has a really good premise and I like how it slowly develops. What I don't like is how the ending is left hanging.


Here are some positive things that you should expect from this show. I am just glad this show is slow-paced. They really took the time to develop Yona and the 4 dragons. Second is its fan service. Don't expect a lot of that and if there is a fan service, they handle it subtly which I am glad because most fan service today are not handled very well. Lastly is it's comic relief. This show can really share a lot of it's funny moments. I love how they handle moments when it's time to laugh and time to be serious. There aren't any weird transitions between the two. The timing of the comedy is great on this anime.


The animation is really good. The coloring maybe decent, but the art style is really creative. The animation does have its moments, but then there are moments where they decided to place random still-frames especially when it comes to fight scenes. 


Where the show truly shines is the Soundtrack. It really fits the setting of Akatsuki no Yona especially that first opening. This is the very first anime I watched where an opening are just instruments playing and it's amazing. That's the "first" opening. When the second opening came, well, it's crap. I mean, it sounds epic when you see the visuals of the opening which makes you pumped up. Without its visuals, the opening is meaningless.


Another thing where the show shines are it's characters. Again, you can really see on how Yona slowly develops, Hak on why he wants to protect the Princess, and Yun on why he wants to travel around the world. Don't forget to mention the 4 dragons. All 4 dragons have different powers (obviously) and different attributes. Each of them have a different attitude because of where and how they grew up, but they only have on idea - to protect Princess Yona (Apparently, Yona is somewhat a reincarnation of Hiryuu - the king that the dragon protects).


Overall, this show very good. The character development, the soundtrack, and the humor is the reason why I like this anime. If you like Shonen anime (I know this is a Shojo anime), well give this show a shot and you might not regret it.

Just a short review, I'll do a better one later.
I liked this anime a lot. It was at a time when I didn't have anything on my list that was really grabbing my attention (I watch several anime's at once) and it was so fun and lovely that I watched it straight through without moving to another story. To me, that is usually a sign that this story has good entertainment value *nods.* 
It has romance, yes, but it's not rushed at all, nor is it too much in your face, if you know what I mean. It feels more like an historical drama/ mythology,but done pretty well (I've had some bad experience with historical dramas, like Night Raid). A lot more going on here than romance. Political upheaval, survival, loss, war, friendship, and a coming of age story.


I really liked how strong Yona is as a woman and as a character. She has a definite arc throughout the story, and I found myself really cheering for her by the end. And even better than that was Hak. He makes the story. His strength and loyalty are almost beyond belief, but instead of being turned off by the absurdity, I ended up really admiring him and rooting for him in his struggles and romantic endeavors. He makes a good straight man to some of the more comical characters, too. There seemed to be a pretty good balance between action, romance, drama, and comedy in this story, a thing that is pretty hard to pull off, I know. I think part of this strength lies in that it doesn't try to do too many genre's at once. It doesn't try to mix in sci-fi or slice of life. It just sticks to its points and fills them out pretty well.


But I didn't give it a 10, because it didn't have the WOW factor. It was great, I would definitely recommend it, but it needed just a little bit more to really knock your socks off. The ending does leave you hanging, though, so I see a second season in the works. I'll be there when that happens.


P.S. I also happened to like the opening theme songs. Just sayin.

I put off watching this anime for fear of being disappointed - boy am I glad I finally persuaded myself to watch the whole thing (in one sitting of course!). This anime was able to use common anime tropes while avoiding some of the more common pitfalls of peers.
Story:
This anime veils its true story until several episodes in, but after that point its fairly predictable and par for the course as far as I'm concerned. The major complaint I have with this anime is that it has moments of cringe-inducing melodrama that impaired my ability to enjoy the actually touching scenes. 
Art:
Solidly animated at alltimes - a clear love project from the animation team. The eyes are expressive and reflect the intention of the characters nicely. The fighting was much more impressive than I expected, even the super-human characters movements are all animated and look natural. The backgrounds were fleshed out and I never felt that something was poorly done. I admire the amount of work that clearly was put into this.\n\n
Sound:\n
So normally I don't put much into this category because usually they're an after thought; however the soundtrack for this anime fits it so perfectly that it deserves special mention. Why is "Sound" rated only a 7 then? Well, if you watch the anime, you'll notice that the intro was changed midway through (as always) but I feel like they completely botched the music choice for it. They went for the most generic "anime intro song" that I can't like no matter how many times I listened to it, which is a shame really because everything else auditory was fantastic.\n\n
Character:\n
I am a firm believer of Chekhov's Gun (Google it) in storytelling - and some anime tend to ignore this principle entirely, making entire arcs that don't matter to the actual story in the slightest. Akatsuki no Yona is not one of those anime. All of the side characters matter well after their introductory episode(s) and more importantly events that happened previously are referenced without the heavyhanded use of flashbacks. I am extremely pleased to report that there was virtually no fan service for all of the 24 episodes (even though they even went into a brothel once). I'm so sick of pointless panty shots of characters and the sexualizing of girls well underage here in the U.S. Even though the main character is female and there are clearly several love interests, there wasn't even the slightest hint of nudity. Anything perverted with Yona would have been tasteless and completely out of character anyway; for not sinking that low the creator's of this anime have my respect.\n\n
Enjoyment:\n
I enjoyed Akatsuki no Yona quite a bit and will definitely be on the lookout for a potential new season in the future. With well above average character development and non-filler side characters, Akatsuki no Yona earns a very solid thumbs-up from me!

Brief synopsis
It is Princess Yona’s 16th birthday and the question that everybody’s asking is who is she going to marry now that she is of marrying age? Yona has her heart set on her cousin, Su-Won, who she adores. As Yona goes to plead her case with her father, who objects to this union, she finds herself embroiled in a catastrophic event that results in her fleeing from her kingdom into wild, new territory and seeking the help of a band of rogue warriors to reclaim what is rightfully hers.
Story
The show’s premise was not especially interesting. It reminded me of Nickelodeon’s Avatar: The Legend ofAang, what with its motley cast of rebels travelling the world, trying to bring peace to warring tribes each named after a different element. However, this show lacked Avatar’s charm, deeper messages of tolerance, and awesomely choreographed fight scenes. It also suffered issues with its pacing. By the show’s completion its primary conflict had barely begun to be resolved. Nevertheless, I did find myself enjoying the show somewhat. It was easy to follow and made for a nice bit of mindless viewing.


Characters

Whilst no particular character leapt out at me as being especially interesting or lovable, there were a wide variety of them, each with their own unique set of characteristics. Particularly impressive was the fact that the show was able to dedicate time to developing the backstory of every main character and many of the supporting cast. And whilst I expected to be annoyed by the helplessness of the titular character, she really did try her best to become more independent and stronger as the show progressed – even if she did have to be rescued countless times! My only real problem was with that irritating squirrel, Ao. I couldn’t stand that thing or the annoying, un-squirrel-like noises it was constantly making. I’ve never understood the need to give a princess a cute, animal sidekick. It wasn’t cute, it wasn’t funny, it was irritating and actually detracted from my enjoyment of the show.


Art

The art was attractive. At points, it was even quite beautiful. Yona’s world was colourful and every important character had interesting elements of visual design.


Music

This was probably my favourite aspect of the show. Whilst there were a couple of gaffes, e.g., the forgettable techno-pop second opening, the music, which made full use of many traditional Eastern instruments, was generally outstanding and in keeping with the show’s historical drama genre.


Overall enjoyment

Whilst Akatsuki no Yona had its problems, e.g., with its unexceptional premise and pacing, it was better than I expected and was still somewhat enjoyable. What the show lacked in gripping story it started to make up for with its generosity in terms of character development and pleasing art and music. I’m not sure whether I’d recommend it to anybody, but I certainly wouldn’t passionately persuade anybody against watching it either.

Story! 6
I thought that the story, or the initial events leading to the core of the story, were a little random. Most of the foreshadowing is in Yona's red hair, and then suddenly she's the descendant of this random king who is the centre of this group of random dragons and there isn't a lot of explanation. You, as the audience, are expected to accept this turn of events and Yona's inevitable destiny. 
On the surface level, however, the plot moves from dragon to dragon in a very natural succession that makes it flow smoothly. It verges on a grittiness near the end that separatesYona from a lot of reverse harems - it's very refreshing! 


Art! 

The art is appealing. The fighting sequences aren't anything to write home about, but they aren't clunky or awkward. The character designs are definitive and bright and modern. 


Sound! 

The instrumentals are phenomenal!!  It's simply impossible to skip the second opening, which is so appropriately intense and lovely. The music is very fresh and caters to the time period of the series. 


Character! 

The characters are all tropes, to be honest, but they work into the series so efficiently and effortlessly that they form a family. They each have a unique, powerful backstory that carries the majority of the series, aside from the fate of the fantasy countries this series is set in. What's more important, is that the female-female relationships are made just as important as the female-male relationships. 

I'm assuming that out of all the characters, Yona gets the most criticism. She makes the turn in her personalities - from spoiled princess to courageous warrior - rather quickly, it's true, but the motivations behind her development are very earnest. She isn't an insufferable heroine, just unrealistic, but in terms of the series she makes a great lead, and her kindness is well balanced with her determination to stick to her morals. 


Overall! 

Akatsuki no Yona offers a very enjoyable series for people who are looking for something fluffy and of good quality (although it gets a little less fluffy when it comes to Zeno's backstory - I literally sobbed). The politics of different characters and countries are covered, if not in depth, and furthermore the characters all have relationships (good or bad) with one another that are dynamic and unique and sometimes challenging to the series, which offers something different than a lot reverse harems that don't want to work for it.

[DISCLAIMER: minor spoilers ahead]
Trust. The faith that we humans put in others hoping that they will not break it in return. But when that faith is broken by the one we held most closest to our hearts, in the most brutal way possible, how can one not help but lose their trust in humanity? In Akatsuki no Yona we see our heroine - the Princess Yona - extend the arm of love and compassion despite suffering from a bitter betrayal.
The momentum of Akatsuki no Yona kicks in right from the first episode with the chirpy tone being undercut by something more sinister - instantly grabbingone’s attention. The pacing is generally quite good, but are times when the plot is somewhat disrupted by frequent flashbacks, but those are mainly in the first third of the anime. Whilst Yona is a shoujo anime, it doesn’t shy away from violence. There are plenty of fight scenes to keep you in your toes, but they aren’t just there for simple entertainment purposes - fight scenes include the psychological analysis of various characters. Romance is not a driving factor in the anime, either. Yes, it is made clear from the beginning that Yona is very much in-love with her cousin, Soo-Won, but this isn’t a story about how Yona is pining for him whilst wanting to murder him. There’s no “I love you so much, but you killed my Father therefore I’m going to end your life, and mine, in a Shakespearean murder-suicide”. Instead, the line between hate and love is blurred and whilst Yona’s difficulty to completely throw Soo-Won away is important to the plot, romance is really not a priority. The anime instead focuses on putting Yona and her entourage in situations that will test them and our heroes go through a lot of hassle to get to where they are at the end of the anime. Friendship, betrayal, suffering and other important themes are well-explored within the 24 episodes.


Furthermore, the anime is not afraid to tackle difficult subject matter in order to test the strength, resolve and resilience that Yona has been building throughout the length of the show. I won’t talk too much about it, but anime can have the tendency to deal with such matters in an insensitive way sometimes. But in Akatsuki no Yona, the issue is dealt with tact and nobody’s dignity is compromised in the process.


As the main character of the show, the anime is essentially Yona’s story. The story of a once weak, naive, sheltered and - sometimes - spoiled young girl who fights to become a woman of strength, honesty and wisdom. Yona does more than just find four dragons on her journey through the Kingdom that her father once ruled: she grows up and forces herself to become resilient to her own suffering so she can help others alleviate their terror. We see Yona put others before herself. Her fellow companions attempt to shield Yona from stepping into something serious and encourage her to depend solely on them, but she refuses. She refuses to remain docile and ignorant.  Yona’s resilience and passion makes her remarkable person. She is unlike any shoujo female protagonist that I have ever encountered, in that she goes through the most character development and it is her character trajectory that proves to be of most importance. There’s no need to worry about a wet-wipe of a heroine who can’t even think for herself. Yona is not just the heroine in name, but in what she does as well.


Hak, dubbed the Thunder Beast for his brute strength and skill in battle, is more than just a raging warrior that his nickname makes him out to be. As Yona’s bodyguard and trusted childhood friend, he is conflicted between making her rely him for 100% protection and allowing her to become stronger on her own. Despite the emotional tirade that Hak seems to be fighting within, he still manages to be teasingly humorous and relaxed when the time calls for it. It’s what sets him apart from other shoujo loyal-dog types. He’s not brooding nor is he bitter: he is, at heart, a selfless man who doesn’t mind being sidelined as long as it makes the people he loves happy. He might be righteous, but that doesn’t make him dull. He’s one of my favourite characters on the show - after Yona - but he wouldn’t be if he was the irritating silent and ‘cool’ type who always protects his master from the shadows (and never has anything nice to say). Hak is up-front and honest in everything that he does (even if Yona doesn’t always catch on to his true intentions) and that is what makes him so lovable.


To round it up, the third main character is Soo-won - our main antagonist. However, I’d be lying if I said I hated him. Akatsuki no Yona doesn’t give us a flat and psychotic villain with a laughable motivation. Instead we are presented with the counter to our heroine, he is not the epitome of evil as most villains are. Dishonest and cunning he may be, but Soo-won doesn’t believe that he is actually doing anything wrong - and it’s somewhat hard to disagree with his motivations. He seeks to repair weaknesses within the Kingdom of ... whilst uniting the five tribes in order to both strengthen the country against outside invasion and improve the lives of his subjects. His motivations are, essentially, honest but the way he goes about doing thinks is morally reprehensible. In my opinion, his character his full of nuance and I’m interested to see how he progresses once I catch up with the manga (and if the anime gets a second season).


The cast of supporting characters are also very interesting and there wasn’t one that I felt was unnecessary baggage. Although they are developed to varying degrees, in relation the amount of time they have on-screen, we get a clear indicator of their personalities and they all complement each other whilst adding depth to the show. 


Don’t let the number of men put you off watching Akatsuki no Yona. This is a far-cry from a reverse-harem series. Yona’s entourage (excluding Hak) might be devoted to her and care deeply for her, but there’s none of this “I must protect Yona because her heart calls to my heart” garbage that we so often see in shoujo with a lot of dudes.


As well as a good plot and well-developed characters, Akatsuki no Yona also has some of the most beautiful animation I’ve ever seen. The colours, character designs and sceneries are a real treat. The actual animation, itself, is also very well done. Characters are never seen in still shots and the fight scenes are animated with fluidity and precision. The soundtrack is also gorgeous - with the second ending theme being one of the most beautiful things I ever heard. I especially appreciated the inclusion of more traditional sounding East Asian music and instruments as well. There’s also some pretty outstanding voice work as well (nothing ever sounded stilted and flat): with the Yona herself having a very emotional and nuanced performance. Chiwa Saito really captures the highs and lows of Yona. Special shout-out also goes Yuusuke Kobayashi who manages to make Soo-won sound both lovable and detestable. 


Overall, I think Akatsuki no Yona is a great anime that was able to capture me from start to finish. It’s both moving and entertaining as well as wonderfully produced. I do hope it gets renewed for a second season because there were plot points and characters that needed development. It also ended in a way that suggests the studio wants to go ahead and adapt the rest of the material of the manga - that leaves me hungry for more.

Many anime struggles to achieve a very smooth and gradual development for their characters. Akatsuki no Yona is a dazzling dawn in that sense, since it is one of the few recent series that nails character development. Yona is officially on my list of favourite female protagonists. It is so amazing when you watch some of the later episodes of Akatsuki no Yona and go back to the very beginning. There is a massive shift to the atmosphere she possesses even though her appearance has gone through almost no change at all. It almost feels like a different anime. 
The anime starts off with Yonaand group of guys behind her ready to interrupt what looks like an army heading to war. We see Yona as a leader, leading us to believe that this series will be action packed, war based anime. But after the quick (beautiful) opening, we are presented with a setting of a peaceful country and a princess that knows nothing about hardship. Yona is portrayed as a spoilt and naive girl in love, to whom everything is provided, from food, abundance of clothes, accessories, affection, guards,etc. But this life of her doesn't continue for long as it crumbles before her eyes during the second half of the episode. And now we are left with many question, few of which are "Where is the Yona we saw at the very beginning? And how does she get to that point?". And hence, we set off on a journey to see her grow as a person from experience, learn about her country and become stronger/independent.   


As you can guess from the title, the main focus is Yona. Therefore, other characters, compared to her, has less screen time, excluding Hak (Yona's childhood friend and her guard). However, that is not to say they are boring in any way. They all have their set of personalities, motives and back story that is unique to them. This makes every encounter during Yona's journey with new characters an interesting one. All the characters, however, are there to influence and take further Yona's character. 


Art style, while is decent throughout, has moments of brilliance sprinkled all over the series. The soundtrack is also something to take note of. While I do believe the amount of soundtracks in this series is less compare to other 24 episode series I have seen (thus, there is a lot of repeated background tracks), they are without a doubt beautiful. Therefore, I welcomed their repeated use. They provided the right vibe and atmosphere, and complimented the series very well. 


Following our main lead and her group may sound a bit too simple for a story. There is an overarching plot that has yet to start undergoing. Akatsuki no Yona simply served to provide a very rich cast of well developed characters. It allowed us to know them, inside out. It is merely a beautiful preparation towards a second season which is obviously on its way. This first half, as good as it is, will not make sense if there is no second season. The ending is, thankfully, a satisfying conclusion for season 1, going back full circle to how we started at the very beginning. The anime fulfilled its purpose of taking us on a well paced journey with many many uplifting, emotional and adorable moments to show us how Yona reached the Yona we saw in the first few second of the series.


I leave a score of 8.7 as I eagerly wait for its continuation.

"Yona of the Dawn" is an adaptation of the manga by Mizuho Kusanagi.
STORY (8):
The story "Yona of the Dawn" takes place in the kingdom of Kouka. Yona is living in Hiryuu Castle with King II and her bodyguard, Son Hak. When Yona was about to show her true love for Soo-Won, things took a turn for the worst when Soo-Won killed King II and planned to take over the kingdom of Kouka. Due to this terrible incident, Yona and Son Hak were forced to leave the country. Along the journey they met Ik-Su &Yun. Ik-Su tells them that in order to save the kingdom of Kouka, Yona & Son-Hak has to find the 4 remaining dragons. So Ik-Su sends Yun to join with Yona & Son-Hak. 


This anime is a journey in search for the 4 remaining dragons. Dragons are referred to the guys who have unique combat skills. 


The story followed the traditional way of storytelling about setting up a character, sending them on their journey and learning more about them through their journey. This anime managed to do that well.


Although this anime was cliché at parts like people do nothing, this anime at least took the time to improve the 4 dragons including Son-Hak & Yun's relationship with Yona.


ART (9):


The animation style is good. The animation also uses comedic elements when there is any light-hearted moments.


SOUND (9):


The opening and ending fits the tone of the music especially in the anime itself. This resembles like in ancient 


CHARACTER (8):


I was very surprised to see a main female character who is strong and determined just like in the anime itself. Her name is Yona. She is beautiful but also determined to succeed no matter what happens. Chiwa Sato embodies the character of Yona well. I also did like her relationship with Son-Hak. Yona showed a lot of character growth when she travelled along with Son-Hak and finding the 4 remaining dragons. In the later episodes, Yona becomes a badass just like Son-Hak and the 4 dragons. Yona is one of the best main female character I have seen.


Son-Hak is like a father-figure to Yona. When he teaches her how to use the bow, he showed compassion and he wanted her to learn how to develop combat skills. His backstory was handled well.


Soo-Won is an interesting character, he could be an anti-hero. However, I wished that we would at least give more backstory to him on why he killed King II, Yona's father.


I also did like Yun. He is distant to nobles. I also liked his backstory the most. He is distant to nobles just like being distant to popular culture. He reminded me so much of Hachiman Hikigaya who never want to be part of the majority and instead have his own private life. Yun is one of my favourite characters in this anime along side with Yona.


I liked Shin-Ah's relationship with Yona although he is stoic and has no social skills. I did like the way how he opens up to Yona and her gang.


I also like Ki-Ja's personality that is straightforward and polite.


I did like Jae-Ha's charm and affection towards Yona.

It is very interesting that the names Jae-Ha, Shin-Ah & Ki-Ja were names that are inspired by Korean artists.

Dear Whoever is Reading This,
My absolute favorite genres are fantasy and romance and I just knew that "Yona of the Dawn" was a must watch.

Akatsuki no Yona has been tagged as one of the strongest shoujo ever made not because it deviates from cliches but rather took these cliches on account and reinvented it.
Having said that, the premise where Akatsuki no Yona is based has been used already over time. Girl travels to find allies in order to take back what is rightfully hers, she meets them and grew accustomed with each other. However, it takes great mastery to turn something not original into something that is refreshing and that is where Akatsuki no Yona proved to be the strongest. 
What would you do if you were betrayed bythe one you loved the most?


This question sparked the start of Yona's struggle and adventure. When she witness her father died by the sword of her beloved Su-Won her world fell apart. Being the princess that she is, she's been sheltered her whole life and knew only happiness. Having a loving father, a caring special someone, a loyal friend and a whole kingdom supporting her contributed on how trusting and simpleminded she is. But her perfect world crumbled before her very eyes and thus marked the beginning of her painful journey.


While it seems that everything has been taken away from her, Hak, her ever loyal friend protected her, helped her, and supported her. You can see the feelings he held for Yona all this time. With flashbacks of their time together, Yona, Su-won and Hak made the strongest childhood friendship so much that it hurts watching things unfold for them.


Akatsuki no Yona is full of interesting characters that will make you watch out for them. Even the supporting ones did a good job to make Yona stronger and fiercer where the situation calls for it. You can see the strong emotions play on Yona's face as she deal with her inner strife. It was fulfilling to watch her grow you can't help but be proud of her.


"No matter how foolish or incomprehensible, some love cannot be discarded. You may try to stop your heart, unable to forgive yourself, but there will be times when you lose hope and your heart is moved again." ~ Ik-soo


Romance and love play an important role in shoujo anime, however, Akatsuki no Yona pulled it off in a subtle way. While the story didn't dwell on romantic relationships between the characters, you know that it's definitely there. You can feel how strong the feelings are. All the tension, hesitation, despair and love that is beyond comprehension. All these are present and were portrayed beautifully.


Akatsuki no Yona managed to deliver shoujo with dignity. In a genre where often the princess is swept off her feet by her prince, Yona, on the other hand, will prove to you that a real princess will not stay behind his prince but rather stand side by side with her knight to fight - for herself and for what she think is right.

Believe it or not I actually dropped this half way through episode one because I expected it to be just another generic shoujo/romance anime. Boy was I terribly wrong. And boy am I glad I gave it a second chance.

STORY. It starts out as a typical shoujo genre with the MC's (main characters) in a one-sided love triangle-esque web. (At least that is how it isportrayed in the anime thus far.) This web consists of a noble boy, a princess, and her loyal bodyguard/general. Everything changes once the first episode ends. The princess's love betray her and she is forced to leave her kingdom along with her loyal bodyguard. Thus the journey of the princess and her loyal bodyguard embarks. They come across a priest and his companion. The priest informs her the story long ago of a king and his four guardian dragons. He then tells her that she must gather the dragons. The princess, her bodyguard, and the priests companion then set on a journey to find the four guardian dragons: the white, blue, green, and yellow dragons.


(Sorry if I made the story sound much more boring or lame than it actually is. My summary obviously does not do this story justice.)


ART. One word: BISHIES. (Just kidding, not kidding.) The art is beautifully breath taking. Exactly how a shoujo genre's art should be.

ENJOYMENT. I enjoyed this series a little too much. Much more than I anticipated. This made me laugh, cry, smile, and it warmed my heart. I applause it for being able to merge the genres romance, comedy, and adventure so well.

This is my first review I have ever written. It is based purely on watching the anime and nothing else. No research into the producer etc.
To start this off, I have to say that this anime is what I was missing for the longest of time. It is one of the few anime that I eagerly wait for the moment it airs and watch it the first moment I get. Even so with all the greatness that is to be described below, there are some parts that makes me unable to give a clear full rating for this anime.
I shall go into the good partfirst and the poorer part last.



Art - 9 :

I wont say that the animation is the greatest, but it is one of the finer ones I have seen. The art makes the character feel that they belong there. The world and the character blends in nicely. The one part that keeps me from giving a 10 on this is the comedy. Although I liked the comedy to soften the dull mood some of the scenes give, they transition badly and sometimes feels forced in some of the scenes thus ruining the consistency. Even so, it is part of the show and it sometimes give depth to the character in expressing parts of the character not easily shown to the viewers.


I especially enjoy the second ending. I enjoy looking at still line art and the ending has tons of those. The effects added in makes it more than just a plain slide show.



Sound - 9:

It is rare that any anime would opt for an instrumental only opening. Initially it gave me an impression that its going to be like "gokukoku no brynhildr", which is the only other anime I watched with an instrumental opening. But giving it another chance, after watching 2 episodes in, it did not feel out of place at all. Its one of the piece that I dont mind listening to for hours and hours. Another great piece was the second ending. Akiko Shikata's style of singing made this show that much more enjoyable. I eagerly await the album release of the second ending.


As for the sounds used in the show, most of them blend well making you feel part of the show. It complements the show in bringing out the excitement and the sadness when it is supposed to.


One bad thing about the sound that I have to comment. The second opening. With all the instrumental folk tracks used in the show, the second opening surprised me to be a electric, rock piece. It took me half way into the second cour before getting over the shock of having electric rock in such an anime.



Character - 8:

Character development of the protagonist and the supporting characters are mostly well done. The protagonist especially gets her story and reason slowly unveiled through the show. The comedy scenes helped in showing beyond the serious tone that most of the show is in. However, there are several characters that I have to point out that did not get any show time. 


The Yellow Dragon - Did not make its debut until the very final episode and didnt get much face time even so. Needless to say, there isnt any character development at all.


Su-Won - We never really did understand his reasons for for doing what he did. It is said that he was avenging his father very early on but further down, it is hinted that he has other reasons as well.



Story - 7*:

Before you judge. It isnt that bad. There are reasons for the score of 7 which ill explain.


First off, the show starts out rather fast. Yona was betrayed by her childhood friend and lost everything she knew by episode 3. Even so, the rest of the show have good pacing and the arks were fleshed out nicely.


The over-arking storyline was simple. Gather the 4 dragons from wherever they are and save the country in the time of darkness. By episode 23, only 3 dragons were gathered which left me to see how the show would end with its last episode and 1 more dragon to gather. And lo and behold, it ended as I have expected. The dragon just joins the party. Nuff said. Well, even the character agrees that it is way too simple. This leaves me completely unsatisfied and craving to know the story of the last dragon. Who is he?


Also, the ending. The important question was finally asked. What are you going to do with the 4 dragons? Not explained either. The ending was nothing but rushed, completely rushed. 


*I gave the story a 7 and if there are any sequel after this at all, it would immediately change to 9. 

(Yes I took this idea from Arkada from Glass Reflection)



tl;dr, If you like story set in the medival/feudal era. This would be a good show for you. Just dont expect a round and complete ending with the happy and fluffy feeling that it ended nicely.

Akatsuki no Yona deals with betrayal of someone you love, and politics. Their is a hidden romance story within the anime but its not the main focus. Summary: 
Upon her sixteenth birthday, the cheerful Princess Yona intended to tell her doting father of her love for Soo-won, but her life was turned upside down after witnessing the man she loves cruelly assassinating her father. Heartbroken by this painful betrayal, Princess Yona fled the palace with her loyal servant Hak. Yona of the Dawn: The Ani-TAY Review
Amazing:
-A Shoujo take on Shounen Adventures
Yona of the Dawn is the grand amalgamation of a shounen adventure that has been refined and revamped into a shoujo form. The selling point is action and adventure rather than romance, but it is calmed down with reason and sophistication. At the same time, it manages to pull you into its fandom through its remarkable ability to appeal to everyone. Whether you’re male or female, a fan of shounen, shoujo, action or romance, there is something to be found in this show for all. 
Ever notice that every fighter inexplicably has some kindof jumping capability in your standard shounen? This is not the case for Yona of the Dawn, for powers are subtle and proportionate. No-one is creating energy in their palms, no-one is harnessing the elements at will. Only a single person in the world has this jumping capability. Rather than trying to impress by making things bigger, faster, and stronger, the show promotes its action with efficiency and strategy. Rather than perpetually gaining new powers to surpass that of their opponents’, characters use the few powers they have to their fullest. The only exception to this is Hak, but he is just one powerful badass with a guandao that gives him an eight foot advantage. In all, the resulting entertainment is the same, but Yona of the Dawn’s means just come off as more realistic, calm, and collected, making it feel more like a shoujo. 


-Realization and Resolution

Yona’s reformation is highlighted not only by her broken ignorance, but also by her desire to do something about this world. There is nothing worse than a show that introduces a dumb, delusional, absent-minded, or plainly ignorant main character which then leaves them undeveloped for a long period of time. If an anime stays like this for too long it becomes an annoyance for viewers. A pampered princess will never know how terrible the world can be unless she herself is thrown into it. In Yona of the Dawn however, an escape from these fears comes impressively sooner than expected. Yona’s mentality quickly sways from that of a helpless princess who always relies on others to that of a heroine who strives to take action into her own hands. 


As viewers, we don’t want to see a hero that’s just dead weight. We want someone interesting enough to get behind. We want to see motivation, determination, a sense for what is right! Yona’s character development is more than satisfactory in this regard. She’s not just a pretty princess anymore!


This show holds a pretty deep insight into how kings are viewed by their people. King Il may have been introduced as a harmless soul, but this superficial quality means nothing to many people. What’s really important to an average person is how they particularly benefit from their ruler. Sure, everyone living in the capital is fine, and that’s where Yona would have conjectured that her father was a great king, but almost everyone who does not live in the capital (or a tribe’s epicentre for that matter) seems to be living in poverty. The people Yona meets on her journey mention that a good king would’ve surely saved them from demise. What is special here is that after Yona learns of these perspectives, she overwrites her own. This is a world that needs change, and Yona figures that out. You can see that she makes an internal resolve to save these people.


-The Preservation of Innocence

Let me enlighten you; there is no fan service in Yona of the Dawn, full stop. *Drops mic* - round of applause - standing ovation. This show is truly in the minority and it receives my sincerest praise for this fact. Yona is untouched by obscurely angled cameras, conspicuous wind, violating entanglements, ripped clothes, and most of all, tripping into a cupped position with a fellow cast member. Enough grace cannot be said. 


-The Ambiguity of a Villain. *SPOILERS IN THIS PARAGRAPH*

The new king’s true motives are suspiciously unclear. There is more to him than what meets the eye. He clearly states why he executed his actions, but it just seems like he truly cares for Yona. He tries to scare her out of the throne room before others come in, almost hinting that it’d be dangerous to stay. When others do show up, he asserts to merely capture her. Once she escapes, he sends no immediate dispatch. When he learns of her supposed death, he seems to falter. Upon the unexpected reunion, he makes sure to conceal her identity. This must all mean something. The speculation is really up for grabs, but everything feels to be pointing towards anti-heroism. Whatever his reasoning, his character is a good subject for delving into and holds promise for the future. 


-Is this a Disney Animation?

This thought couldn't escape my mind throughout the entire production. I don’t mean this in the sense that Yona of the Dawn feels western, but more refer to the fact that it fills the Disney checklist. We’re given an amazing soundtrack, beautiful character design, lovable and well written characters, a story that can be adored by youth and has more to offer to adults, a main heroine with a cause that we can all root for, a supportive cast, the staple animal companion (“Best rodent sidekick in anime since Pikachu." - Koda Kazar. See below), an initial plot twist that throws everything out of whack, the recuperation journey that follows, and an evolution for the better within the main character. This show has almost everything, the only thing missing are the musical numbers. Kind of reminds you of Mulan now, doesn’t it? 


-Don’t Mess with the Raijuu 

“Son Hak. The grandson of Son Mundok, former head of the Wind Tribe, he rose to lead the tribe at a young age. A single blow from his blade is like lightning, earning him the nickname of the ‘Thunder Beast (Raijuu) of Kouka.’” Hak is without a doubt the strongest fighter in Kouka. He is brave, strong, and persevering, but none of these words do enough justice when trying to describe him. Without him, Yona would have easily died on multiple occasions, that is, if her journey would have even been able to start in his absence. We have seen him take on dozens of men at once and succeed, survive falls that would have left anyone else dead or paralyzed, heal from cuts that were more than just flesh wounds, and yet, maintain his bad-ass composure. In all fairness, Hak may seem a bit overpowered compared to everyone else, but his power is both still possible in the limits of this world and a key element of the story. With such a stature, reputation, and weapon, who wouldn’t hesitate in the face of Hak?



Okay:


-Taking it Step by Step, Predictably

Thanks to the snippet at the end of episode two, we knew from the start that Yona would find all the dragons. A window into the future can easily be as a hinderance to a story, but in Yona of the Dawn’s case, there was no way in hell that Yona wasn’t going to find all the dragons. What makes the story better than its superficial find dragon one, find dragon two plot are the trials that the party goes through to recruit each dragon. This flash forward focuses the plot on how they will succeed, rather than if they will succeed. It focuses the viewer on the individual dragons and the telling of their own stories and complexities instead of wondering what is to come. 


-How is Yona Alive? *No particular spoilers, just lore*

There are a few scenes in particular across Yona of the Dawn that leave you saying, “oh come on, no-one could live through that,” or, “that guy could have easily killed her.” The answer that most people would jump to is that Yona possesses plot armour. In short, that means she is invincible because she is the main character. While this may be true, I believe that there is a justifiable explanation to this as well. The following is opinionated, but please regard the speculation nevertheless. Yona has the power to subconsciously convey and control. Take, for example, the fact that Yona can stun the four dragons by just being in their presence. This is possible because she is the reincarnation of the dragons’ tamer from 1000 years ago, Hiryuu. Hiryuu was a divine incarnation who was able to conquer the country along with the four dragons. If you ask me, this would be impossible to do with just five people, but persuasion changes everything. By sharing Hiryuu’s soul, Yona is able to subconsciously restrain people and stop them from dealing harmful blows.


Keep in mind that this is all just speculation, so believe what you will, but in the very least it makes sense. As for her method of conveying (and this one is easy), it’s all in her eyes. I don’t care who you are, you would stutter and take a second thought after Yona hits you with her powerful gaze. Those eyes are weapons in their own right and if you think I’m just gabbing, take a look at this:



Terrible:


-This Cut-Off Point is A Buzzkill

The show has really just started ramping up; to stop now seems almost criminal. There was a great deal of time to get to know the first three dragons and have their characters develop and fleshed out. Then came the fourth. How do you expect to make an integral character rememberable with 10 minutes of airtime? It’s really a shame. 


Believe it or not, a shoehorned character is not the biggest problem here. Yona’s found the four dragons, she’s said her plan, and now it’s time to start going at it, right? Wrong! First you need to split the story in the middle, wait for more content to be written, hope the BluRays sell, then you continue. Depending on how the BluRays do sell, this show will either be a prologue to one hell of an adventure, the amazingly adapted first season to a show that fell short for all the wrong reasons, or in the worst case a show with no sequel at all. 



Conclusion:


Looking over what we have here, Yona of the Dawn is well done anime that just isn’t done yet. This is a timeless adventure with characters we can all get behind, animated in a beautiful shoujo style. It is a mature take on genres that we already love and it takes itself seriously in that regard, never faltering. When considering watching this show, you only have to ask yourself one question: do I want to watch a story that is halfway done, or wait until it’s finished? A good portion of the time this answer is no, but in the case of Yona of the Dawn, there is no harm. This prologue, if I may, stands on its own as a recuperation journey and a path to revealing the truth. Not only that, when the second season does come along, the only thing that you’ll be required to remember is that Yona has assembled the four dragons. Without a doubt Yona of the Dawn is a Go For It! as it stands now, and once complete the show will just be that much better.

I'm going to give this a higher score than what I give it credit it for.
This anime brings forth a main female lead who has escaped from a harsh reality that comes from even the most safe and trusted of people and places. Specifically she loses her home and her trust in things she grew up with since childhood.
It defies the norm in the sense we have a female lead who is hurt by betrayal and is trying to overcome and make the right decision from it, unlike from the ordinary first time a female lead is shown to be a bad-ass and reliable personone can count on. She learns and grows both in character and in philosophy. This and the obvious 'It isn't a male lead.' It has promoted growth and development in character.


This is well told through the storytelling of the show;

She learns how to defend herself and others,

she learns independence,

she learns how to distinguish others demeanor instead of naively trusting them immediately.


And she adventurers along a mix of old and new friends in her party to realize her goal.


It very much reminds me a bit of a more Chinese storytelling rather than a Japanese storytelling but that may just be it visually for background, art, and setting. The action is standard with sometimes our main male lead standing out in his more bold moments.


What I lost interest in was in two things;


The lesser con was the music sounds so great on its own, but I never felt the scenes complimented well with them. One never helped the other standout. I'm either really picky or something just seemed missing in terms of heavy or light moments. It was more character reaction that made things more memorable.


The biggest irritation for me was the lack of focus a high number of times. I get there is a time and a place for everything, but it seemed so segmented rather than fluid in delivery. This would be the back and forth of serious moments to comedic moments as well as the change of art style between shots but in the same scene.


It's jarring and a very agitating way of storytelling. An example comparison to get the idea across is sometimes a scene that includes CGI as a big part of a scene but it did not compliment the previous shots that had none or had that it didn't give introduction to help transition to the CGI segment.

The show will change scene appearance into a very sudden flat shot either for all or just one of the characters and/or its background. A poorly contrasting use to the detailed backgrounds and mood set before it.


A more small minor thing that bothered me was that the latest prophesied dragon/party member was haphazardly put in. Unlike the first three where we got to see backstory, interests, intentions and character. This is probably due to them reaching the last of the episode time/budget.


The standard anime check list is here at least whether you like them or not; Incest love interest (Cousin), the majority of friends have some romantic interest in the lead, the villain has some good in his evil doing, and comedy dialogue to show that our cast isn't always uptight (Although here gets a bit too much.)


It has good moments, but to me, it falls to make sure it does typical norms of the medium and therefore hurts itself into putting greatness into what it has.
