I'm not gonna lie, the only reason why I watched this anime was because of a recommendation list that said it was about a princess gitting gud. Which I am a sucker for good female leads (Moribito being one of my favorite anime.) What I got was a decent little show about a princess in fact gitting gud. Spoilers below though Ill be very vague on them for those wanting to watch this series
(Overall I give this an anime a 6/10 for the TL/DR)
The story is about the female lead Yona turning 16 and having a nice party that suddenly stops being nice when herentire life gets absolutely ruined by a coup. Her peace loving father, and king of the land and has a wopping 5 minutes of screen time, gets murdered and the murderer takes the throne, forcing the young princess to flee with her trusted friend, bodyguard and the male lead , Hak. From there it turns into an adventure story about her wanting to git gud but she's just a clooless pwincess who doesn't know any better. Honestly I am probably making the story seem bad when it actually has potential, shame it never expands on the potential. The coup is never fully expanded upon as the goals of it are never explained in the full 24 episodes this series goes through. The adventure aspect takes up most of it and its pretty good at that, the little arcs the bratty and clueless Yona and her badass hotboi, and albeit creepy, bodyguard Hak, journey together on are very nice as they work well as a duo, key word being duo. Eventually more people tag along as her new goal is to assemble the ancient descendants of dragon warriors to accomplish a goal that is not explained in the entire 24 episodes of this series, such as a very feminine boy genius. A very devout, very naive White dragon descendant. A very edgy Blue dragon descendant. A flirty and rather flamboyant Green dragon descendant. And the biggest offender of this motley crew "I am hungry and Carefree" The yellow dragon descendant. These extra characters don't really add anything aside from more people for Hak to tease but Ill go more into my problems with them when I talk about the characters. Overall with the current ending of this anime I cannot rate this story highly, too many loose ends and it is far too under explained for its own good.


The art is pretty good, some set pieces look really nice and I like the character designs. I especially like Yona's as it makes her look weak and pathetic when it needs too, yet still comes off as confident when needed.


God Bless this soundtrack. I am a massive sucker for eastern instrumentals. That being said no song really stood out, however every song enhanced the scene they were used in by quite a bit. The OP and ED are pretty forgettable though.


Oh boy the characters, I already expressed that I thoroughly enjoyed Yona and Hak as a duo, however though the rest of the cast drag them down, typically stealing the spotlight from one or both of them. As an example at one point Yona must go get these plants in a dangerous cliff side as part of a deal. The condition is that she must do it alone. Well Mr. Green and Flamboyant decides to follow her there to keep her company, alright that's fine. He even states that even he cant go past a certain point as he's too big. So Yona continues onward bravely, despite her being terrified and physically weak she still finds the inner strength to keep going and she actually fucking succeeds without any help. Awesome characterization there. Que an incoming storm from outta fucking no where, and a massive wave happens to hit the cliff side she was at. She falls over but manages to grab onto a tree root that's coming from the cave that has the flowers in them. Awesome, she gets to prove even more how strong she's become. But nah another character crushing wave comes by so Green and Flamboyant comes to her rescue. Stealing the spotlight from what could have been another good moment to show her strong will. Though this happens only a few times. Now the biggest and worst offender to the cast of characters is the Yellow Dragon, he shows up and says that he's carefree and that he's hungry. He appears in episode 23. Amazing and top tier characterization right there. Thankfully the antagonist of this show is a very interesting one, I won't go into much detail about him as I feel he needs to be experienced, as it appears most people have a different opinion on him.


I enjoyed the comedy and what little action the show offers. Most of the comedy comes from the motley crew bickering or bantering, typically the fault of Hak. 


Overall Akatsuki no Yona wanted to tell the story of a princess gitting gud, and it does. Kinda, it feels incomplete. As the ending it has really isn't an ending. It more feels like the end of a long arc. If it had a proper ending I would have given this anime a 7/10 but as it is now It earns its 6/10. Its held back by the extra cast of characters and poor story.

Story: 10

The story of Akatsuki no Yona takes place after the spoiled 16 year-old princess Yona is the victim of a coup d'etat, led by her cousin Soo Won. She and her bodyguard Hak flee the kingdom to avoid being killed, and learn of a destiny they have to achieve in order to reclaim Yona's home. Despite it being a somewhat simplistic plot, I've never really seen it around before, and it has never been executed quite like AnY. Every arc seems to unfold into dangerous territory and most of the time, the characters don't come out completely unscathed. Unfortunate events have our heroes tumbling from place to place, desperately trying to recover from each attack. You never get the sense that these characters are safe, they're constantly on the run from something. It's realistic, even for a fantasy genre, and the way the characters react to each new event feels real and wholesome. But the story isn't the biggest charm point this show has, it's the characters and how they work with the story. Like I said, the plot is simple, but the driving characters are what makes it interesting (and I will talk in-depth about this later).


Art: 10

Okay if I'm honest I wasn't a huge fan of the art at the beginning of the series. Everything was so sparkly and the eyes were so huge and while I absolutely didn't HATE the art, it wasn't anything special. There were a few moments when the animation seemed absolutely brilliant, especially in the chase scenes, but like I said, nothing special. But then, after a few episodes, you get to see how Yona is shaped by the tragedies that surround her, and it's very easy to see her character development through her eyes alone. Her eyes are a huge focal point in the art here, showing her going through the transition from naive girl to fierce warrior. The colors of each scene really help reflect what you should be feeling, from fiery reds to pump you up to cooler, darker blues to make you feel at ease. Basically I'm a huge fan of character development through subtle changes in the characters' appearances and colors, and this is a tactic that AnY executes extremely well. More examples of this can be shown in Hunter x Hunter (2011) and the more tragic arcs of One Piece.


Sound: 9

The first opening of this show is brilliant, as it takes a special type of show to be able to pull off a completely instrumental opening. Its music goes completely in-sync with the visuals and they flow really beautifully into each other. The first ending looks and sounds lovely, though it doesn't hold quite the same impact as the OP. I wish they'd kept the instrumental opening in the second half of the season, as I'm not a huge fan of the 2nd OP. The 2nd ED, however, is so fitting to the show and sounds and looks lovely, to boot. The OST also has some very emotional tracks that I'm very fond of, and overall, the sound of the series is great, although it's nothing TOO fantastic.


Character: 10

I'd give this an 11 if I could. If you watch this show for anything, it should be for the characters. Yona is definitely one of the strongest, most well-developed female characters I've ever seen. It's so refreshing to see a character who is initially a spoiled crybaby progress so well into a fierce, determined fighter, without sacrificing parts of her original charm. She still goofs off and is ignorant to many things, but she WANTS to learn. Yona is pretty much my hero. If you're looking for a strong female character in a series, you don't need to look any further. Despite being the center of a harem, Yona is easily the least romance-focused character in the show. She portrays a realistic female character in danger surrounded by males who love her and want to protect her. That meaning, she doesn't let them protect her. Every time she's saved by someone, she wants to return the favor, and get stronger. She has no time for worrying about her romantic life, and she makes this very clear. 

The other characters aren't without their charm points, either, specifically Hak, Soo Won, Yoon, and the dragons. Hak is incredibly funny and sassy, and badass too. He has his gentle side and obviously cares deeply for Yona (and cared deeply for her father), and he, like Yona, has deep emotional conflict about Soo Won. His interactions with the dragons are hilarious, and he's a likable, relatable character. Yoon is a support character but his development and friendship with Yona is so nice, considering the got off on the wrong foot at the start. The dragons and their interactions are all very wholesome and nice, despite having only known each other for a short time. The backstories are seriously tragic, so if you wanna cry and feel bad for these characters, this is the place to go. As conflicted as Yona and Hak are about Soo Won, I feel this conflict as well. I still don't know how to feel about Soo Won, he's easily one of the best villains I've seen come out of the fantasy genre. Altogether, the characters are what make this show truly enjoyable. If you want strong characters and amazing interactions, this is the show for you. I just wish there could be a season 2 so you didn't have to go read the manga to find out more about the yellow dragon. If you ask me, they chose an awkward time to cut the series off, and a season 2 is basically necessary to enjoy it (or you could read the manga, but who does that now a days? :P)


Enjoyment and overall: 10

This show is an excellent portrayal of what a harem can be, and what a fantasy adventure can be. Yona is an incredible character who still has a loooong way to go, and the other characters support and compliment her in all the best ways. The art and animation are nothing to judge, and the story weaves in with the strong characters very well. If this show doesn't get a season 2, I will be severely disappointed, since the future arcs of the manga have some of the best moments and greatest things to offer. If you want basically anything good out of an anime, I suggest you watch this.

About half way through this series I though I'd give it an overall 7/8. When I finished it, I found that they sill haven;t released season 2, and guess what. I'm not almost caught up with the manga.

Yona of the Dawn: Proof that "Harem" and "Quality Anime" are not mutually exclusive terms.
Coming into the series, I had a fair bit of skepticism. Harem (reverse or not), is just not a genre I usually enjoy. Taking one glance at the character section on MAL did not help. This show is not only a reverse harem, but it is what I would consider a "bishounen" reverse harem. To top if off, there really is no other female characters outside the MC to speak of. SO it's a bunch of hot anime boys whose only romantic option is the protagonist. Now, is that pandering tothe target audience a bit? Sure. But let's not throw the baby out with the bath water. That fact does not preclude this from being a top-notch anime. 


It's very simple, while some might roll their eyes as bishie after bishie is introduced into Yona's growing harem and consider that a negative, the show basically nails every other aspect. I'll explain.


Story: 8

I'm not going to get into specifics of the story and you can read the synopsis to at least get the gist of the set up. But I will say the story, while not mind-blowing, has not enough twist and turns to make it pretty consistently compelling. Each episode will usually leave you wondering what is going to happen next, and usually plays a role in the overall story arc in the series.


Art: 9

Art-wise, it's excellent as well. The animation quality is high across the board and there is some really beautiful shots and cinematography throughout. Also, needless to say, I think female fans will be happy with the design of male characters. Thumbs up.


Sound: 6

Sound-wise, it's ok. The voice acting was good, not great. A lot of the same background music was replayed a lot, and oftentimes way too loudl. I can't say either of the OPs or EDs really stood out either. Sound is the show's weak link, but it's not egregiously bad.


Character: 8 (heads up, this is going to be the longest section)

Now again, it's worth pointing out these characters were very clearly designed to appeal to its target audience, which is not me. But that doesn't mean they're bad. There is a decent mix of goofy and serious characters, and I would say most are likable. I appreciated the fact that not only were the characters different, but the way in which Yona interacted with them were unique for each one.


Now, there's a lot of characters in the show, but I am going to spotlight 3 of them. First, Yona, the main character. She is a sheltered, naive, and overall pretty useless princess that is forced to abandon the castle just to survive. It's very much a sink or swim scenario, and to her credit, she swims. Her character development from the princess everyone has to protect to someone that can protect herself, and sometimes others, is a big part of the series. I'd also like to applaud the realistic progression she shows. No one turns into a BAMF overnight, and neither did she. Overall, she was a solid main character, even if she comes up a bit short in comparison to some of my other favorite shoujo MCs.


Second, we have Hak. He's the bodyguard, and childhood friend, of Yona. Let's it call like it is. Hak is awesome. Yeah you might take a look at him and think he's just eye-candy, but it goes well beyond that. He is an incredibly talented warrior, selfless, devoted, and overall just good dude. Honestly, and I know she's the MC and a princess, but IMO he's out of Yona's league. It's definitely one of those cases where if she wasn't the main character, I doubt he'd be so love-struck. Also, the whole "childhood friend secretly harboring feelings for the oblivious main character" thing has freakin' been done to death. Just stop it already writers. In fact, my biggest complaint was how his entire world seemed to revolve around Yona. It seemed like most conversations and thoughts of his had something to with her. He's a cool enough character that his association with Yona shouldn't completely define him as a person. But I digress, Hak is still awesome. Definitely a top-tier husbando.


Third, Su Won. He is Yona's cousin, and yes, first and only love. Unfortunately, he also murders her father and takes his place as Kouko's next king. This leaves Yona in utter shock, as not only does she love this man, but this action conflicted so heavily with the Su-Won with the gentle smile she knew. We don't see as much from him after this, but it's clear he was very much not alone in this coup d'etat. It leaves both Yona and the viewer in a conflicted state. Is he a monster or a simply monster's puppet? Who is the real Su Won; the man who murdered the king, or the loving cousin that would fall asleep holding Yona's hand? It's not entirely clear, and that's what makes him such an intriguing "villain".


Enjoyment: 8

Good action, good drama, decent comedy. The only thing that hindered my enjoyment was the whole bishounen reverse harem aspect of the show. Although I'm sure its target audience loved that part.


Overall: 8

A really good show, that also has me shaking my head a bit. Because it could've been GREAT if not for the pandering it exhibited with the harem aspect, all the eye candy, and insanely lopsided gender ratio. Having said that, it is definitely the best harem anime I have seen and I think one that even guys can appreciate. I know I did.

This is one of the best traditional Japanese-like anime I have ever watched. If you're a big fan of Hakuouki, you'll fall in love with this. Akatsuki no Yona has been on my plan to watch list for so long and I finally watch it. I have no regrets finishing it in one day.

Akatsuki no Yona, a.k.a Yona of the Dawn, a.k.a The Girl Standing in the Blush of Dawn.
Like 90% of the anime I've watched, Akatsuki no Yona was a rare gem that I randomly found.
Like needle and the haystack.
Except the needle was miniscule, and I stepped on it.
But bleeding for it felt good.
OK, that sounded weird but you have the gist of it.
Amazingly, I've rated all sections 9/10 because of how much I'm in love with it.
*May contain spoilers... oops*
~Story~  (9/10):
The story begins on beautiful, sunny weather.... Hah, you wish. Long story short, the lovely cousin Su-won, who Princess Yona is in love with (Eww),betrays her and Hak, the lovely general, and kicks them out of the castle with soldiers chasing them. Since the princess lost her silver spoon and after watching her father getting killed right before her eyes, she becomes a marionette. Then some priest shows them the way of life and they go on an adventure finding her dragons.


And it is the most awesomest (If that's even a word...) adventure. I don't like weak girls who rely on their super hot bodygaurds just because they said so. No, OK, that's not cool.

That's not the case with Yona.

To protect Hak, her newly acquired friends, and herself, she finds the first dragon. 

To free the dragon she cries over, she takes him away as the second dragon.

The third one is a pervert.

And the fourth is.... yeah.


Point is, during this journey, not only Yona takes up a weapon her father banned and warned her to never touch, she changes from only thinking about herself to thinking about saving her country. I don't know about you, but that's amazing. This season is a world-builder, so that means it's only the beginning. The story is not rushed, it's paced out just fine, and it leaves you with a cliffhanger. 

A good one, OK?


Reason why I didn't give it full marks, was becuase it was a snail's pace at the beginnning, which is both a bad and good thing.


~Art~ (9/10):

I loved the art. I'm no art critic, so, to be honest, I don't know what to write. 


~Sound~ (9/10):

Can an instrumental opening sound soooooo~ good? 

I can hardly believe it. 

Usually, when I listen to the opening once, I skip it during the rest of it.

Not with this one, nope.

The second opening, I found was fantastic, not as great as the first, but still great.

I believe there is sub and dub, but I've only fully watched the sub and a tiny bit of dub.

Dub was OK.

Sub was great.

Don't judge me.

The instrument stood out for me the most, was the flute. It carried a nice tune, and it made the background music a delight to hear.


~Character~ (9/10):

As I said before, Yona became a sissy princess, to a badass red-hair. 

For this season, the flashbacks were mainly about Yona, Hak and Su-won's childhood, when they were still best friends. So, I believe, if we are ever gonna get a second season, the dragon's backgrounds will be revealed. Yona goes under a great change; like metamorphosis- a caterpillar to a beautiful butterfly. But it's not enough, I want to see more~.


Oh, and I love the four dragons, they are so cute and adorable in their own way.


~Overall~ (9/10):

This anime has done a great job in mixing seriousness and comedy; you'll laugh when they laugh, and you'll cry when they cry. 

This anime is suited for those who like reverse-harems, little tiny bits of romance, action, fantasy and historical themes.


It would be no joke to call this one of my favourite animes of all times~
